content:
In hat case you don't need to do anymore than let Thunderbird configure your account for you using the settings here https://autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/gmail.com

If your account set up is not working for some reason, the most likely problem is you third party antivirus product. Defender rarely causes issues. Third party products vary a lot over time, but my experience is Norton's will always cause account set up failure. Others the result varies.

content:
A reinstall rarely does anything constructive, but it has been known to loos everything. But still folk jump to it as a first fix.

My advice is post the actual error message (verbatim) and the details of the mail provider you are having issues with. Reinstalling is most certainly not going to fix your issue unless your antivirus has gone off the reservation and that is far more frequent than folks realize. It could well be your issue now even. If your account is with the Microsoft sponsored hotmail, msn, live, outlook it may well be that you are using the wrong server name but as you have not supplied any information pertinant to provider or type of error all I or anyone can do is guess.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: One possibility would be to create filters for all incoming and outgoing messages. The outgoing would likely need two such filters. Experiment with different approaches to find what works for you. The filters would copy messages to holding folders. That doesn't prevent deletes, but would ensure none were lost. For a perfect solution, you would need a server-driven transaction manager, not Thunderbird. Well, that's my opinion. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content:
Agreed, there is nothing in Thunderbird which will prevent message deletion, nor will there likely ever be.

You could perhaps write an addon https://developer.thunderbird.net/add-ons/mailextensions

content:
The simplest solution is copy the profile on the windows 10 machine and paste it into the windows 11 machine.

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: the fix is rather easy: thunderbird opens the profiles.ini (a simple txt file) at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to find the location of the profile.Edit that with notepad to point to wherever you put it.
creator: davidsk

content: That it is occasional indicates a possible difference in your PC and phone. Thunderbird isn't perfect, but it's consistent in what it does or does not do. For example, if your PC is IMAP and your phone is POP, there would be situations where the message would be on one and not the other. I am not saying that is the problem, but I do suggest a careful review.
creator: davidsk

content:
OK, I dug around a bit and found that in my new TB installation "Provider for CalDAV & CardDAV" had been disabled because "This addon has been discontinued because Thunderbird natively supports this feature".

Well I guess that it does support syncing natively to a certain extent as my calendars were syncing before I enabled the addon again, but it was also causing my notifications not to display: as soon as I enabled the addon again they all popped up.

Fine for now, but I guess at some point the addon will no longer be compatible as it's not maintained, and then it's goodbye notifications again. Looks like a bit of a big bug in TB

content:
Thank you for your reply. I found someone else who had the same problem and his solution worked.

1) Went to my AVG anti-virus program and turned off the email protection. 2) Went back to my email and it was now able to get my emails. 3) Went back to my anti-virus program and turned the email protection back on. 4) Email seems to be coming back in as expected, just fine.

(I had like 500 gigabytes of free space on my hard-drive.) Thank you for trying to help.
